title: Quotes
text: Gathering qoutes that I come across

title: Quotes
text:
2025

Funny thing about getting older your eyesight starts to get weaker but your ability to see through people‚Äôs bullshit gets better. - Anonymous
Agents are not only going to change how everyone interacts with computers. They‚Äôre also going to upend the software industry, bringing about the biggest revolution in computing since we went from typing commands to tapping on icons. - Bill Gates, Co-founder of Microsoft
Any fool can write code that a computer can understand. Good programmers write code that humans can understand. ‚Äì Martin Fowler
In all chaos there is a cosmos, in all disorder a secret order. ‚Äì Carl Jung

title: Quotes
text:
2024

When you focus on you, you grow. When you focus on shit, shit grows - Dwayne Johnson
People do not decide their futures, they decide their habits and their habits decide their futures - F. M. Alexander
Watch your thoughts, they become your words; watch your words, they become your actions; watch your actions, they become your habits; watch your habits, they become your character; watch your character, it becomes your destiny. - Lao Tzu
Travel and tell no one, live a true love story and tell no one, live happily and tell no one, people ruin beautiful things. - Kahlil Gibran
If you spend your time chasing butterflies, they‚Äôll fly away. But if you spend your time making a beautiful garden, the butterflies will come. Don‚Äôt chase, attract. - Japanese proverb
It is impossible for a man to learn what he thinks he already knows. - Epictetus
work is fun and fun is work
When you start taking care of yourself, you start feeling better, you start looking better, and you even start to attract better. It all starts with you. - Anonymous
It may seem difficult at first, but everything is difficult at first. - Miyamoto Musashi
Everything we hear is an opinion not a fact, everything we see is a perspective not the truth. - Marcus Aurelius
Master the mind or you will be a slave to your thoughts
Train your mind. Train your body. Trust in the force - Asoka Tano
You earn a living to Live Well not to kill yourself with stress - Sadhguru
When words become unclear, I shall focus with photographs. When images become inadequate, I shall be content with silence. - Ansel Adams
The happiness of your life depends on the quality of your thought - Marcus Aurelius
Death is sinking into slumbers deep. Birth again is waking out of sleep - Thirukkural
The gap between your current life and the life you want is called Focus - Anonymous
Every positive thought has a negative thought associated with it. - Anonymous
Desire to learn is incredibly scarce in this world. Naval Revikant
Discipline is choosing between what you want now and what you want most - Abraham Lincoln
What get measured get managed
Behaviour is always greater than knowledge. Because in life there are many situations where knowledge fails but Behaviour can still handle - A.P.J. Abdul Kalam
We live in the time of cutting edge obsolescence - John Finger
The idea of progress is built on the notion that if we admit our ignorance and invest resources in research, things can improve. - Yuval Noah Harari

the progress depends on recognizing our lack of knowledge and actively investing in research to address it. By acknowledging what we do not know and dedicating resources to learn and innovate, we can achieve improvements and advancements.

Edison did not look for problems in need for solutions; he looked for solutions in need for modifications - The New Yorker
The man who blames other has a long journey ahead, the man who blames himelf is halfway there, and the man who blames no one has already arived - Chineese proverb
If you don‚Äôt ask the right questions, you don‚Äôt get the right answers. - Robert Half
Worrying doesn‚Äôt take away tomorrow‚Äôs troubles. It takes away today‚Äôs peace. - Annonymous
I have come to believe that the whole world is an enigma ‚Ä¶ a harmless enigma that is made terrible by our own mad attempt to interrupt as though it had an underlying truth. - Umberto Eco
Life is too short to hangout with people who aren‚Äôt resourceful. - Jeff Bezos
The prompt is the fundamental unit of knowledge work. - @IndyDevDan

title: My Google Feed Sent Me to the Edge of the Solar System (and Blew My Mind!)
text:
Scrolling through my Google feed today, a headline caught my eye: ‚ÄúNASA‚Äôs Voyager Spacecraft Found A 30,000-50,000 Kelvin ‚ÄòWall‚Äô At The Edge Of Our Solar System.‚Äù My first thought? ‚ÄúClickbait! This has to be some kind of exaggeration, if not outright fake news.‚Äù After all, 50,000 Kelvin is a temperature usually reserved for the heart of stars, not the cold, empty vacuum of space. So, I did what any curious mind with an AI assistant would do: I asked Claude Sonnet 4 to verify it, specifically checking against official NASA press releases, blogs and scientific papers.
To my astonishment, Claude confirmed the article‚Äôs core claims with high credibility, citing reputable sources like NASA.gov, JPL.nasa.gov, and even peer-reviewed publications. The Voyager spacecraft, or the robotic pioneers launched way back in 1977, did indeed measure extremely high temperatures‚Äîranging from 30,000 to 50,000 Kelvin (that‚Äôs 54,000-90,000¬∞F!) at the heliopause, the very edge of our solar system‚Äôs protective bubble.
So, what exactly is this ‚Äúwall of fire‚Äù and how did we stumble upon it? Our Sun is blowing out a stream of charged particles, called the solar wind. This wind creates a giant, invisible bubble around our entire solar system, known as the heliosphere, extending about 120 times farther than Earth is from the Sun (that‚Äôs 11.2 billion miles!). Everything we know, from Earth to Pluto, resides inside this bubble. At its distant edge, this solar wind slams into the interstellar medium the thin gas and dust between stars. This cosmic collision forms a boundary zone, the heliopause, which the Voyager spacecraft have now successfully crossed.

title: My Google Feed Sent Me to the Edge of the Solar System (and Blew My Mind!)
section: How Far is the ‚ÄúWall of Fire‚Äù from the Sun?
text:
How Far is the ‚ÄúWall of Fire‚Äù from the Sun?

The Numbers:

Distance: About 120 AU from the Sun
In miles: 11.2 billion miles
In kilometers: 18.0 billion kilometers

(AU = Astronomical Unit = distance from Earth to Sun = 93 million miles)


Putting This in Perspective:
Compared to familiar distances:

Earth to Sun: 1 AU
Sun to Pluto: ~40 AU
Sun to Heliopause: ~120 AU

So this ‚Äúwall of fire‚Äù is:

120 times farther than Earth is from the Sun
3 times farther than Pluto!


The ‚Äúfire‚Äù isn‚Äôt literal, of course; there‚Äôs no oxygen for combustion in space. Instead, the astonishing temperature refers to the kinetic energy of the extremely sparse particles at this boundary. Voyager 2‚Äôs Plasma Science Experiment (PLS), which is one of its experiment module, measured the speed and energy of individual particles. The faster these particles jiggle and move, the higher their inferred temperature. While each particle is incredibly energetic, space at this frontier is so empty that there aren‚Äôt enough of them to transfer significant heat to the spacecraft itself. It‚Äôs like being pelted by a handful of super-hot grains of sand ‚Äì individually scorching, but collectively not enough to burn you.
What truly fascinates me about this discovery, beyond the sheer scale of the numbers, is how it highlights the nuances and challenges of the scientific process. When I first read the blog, my immediate thought was, ‚ÄúVoyager is just a tiny speck, a single point of measurement. How can scientists possibly extrapolate that the entire 240 AU-wide heliopause has this uniform temperature?‚Äù This is the question that gets to the heart of scientific validity. Yes - it is a significant limitation.
Scientists do acknowledge this. We currently have direct measurements from only two points - where Voyager 1 and Voyager 2 crossed the heliopause, separated by about 2.6 AU, which is still a tiny fraction of the boundary‚Äôs vastness. Drawing conclusions about the entire heliopause from these two data points is akin to taking the temperature in Montauk, New York City, and declaring it‚Äôs the uniform temperature of the entire Earth. So, how do they justify it? They rely on theoretical models, the agreement between the two Voyager measurements, and indirect observations from other missions (like IBEX - Interstellar Boundary Explore - a space observatory designed to study the far reaches of our solar system from orbit focused on mapping the edge of our solar system). However, they also admit that their initial models predicted a temperature nearly half of what Voyager actually measured (15,000-30,000K vs.¬†30,000-50,000K), indicating that our understanding of this boundary is still evolving.
The higher-than-predicted temperature suggests that processes like compression heating and complex magnetic field interactions at this boundary are more significant than previously thought. The honest scientific position is that while we‚Äôve measured these temperatures at two specific points, and they align with revised theoretical explanations, we don‚Äôt truly know if this temperature is uniform across the entire heliopause, or if it varies significantly in other regions or over time due to solar activity. Sending more probes in different directions would be ideal, but the practical realities of time (40+ years to reach the heliopause), cost (billions of dollars per mission), and engineering challenges make comprehensive mapping incredibly difficult.
Ultimately, the Voyager missions represent an unparalleled achievement in human exploration. They are our first and so far, only‚Äîambassadors beyond our solar system‚Äôs protective bubble. While the ‚Äúwall of fire‚Äù might be a dramatic nickname, the underlying scientific discovery is genuinely astounding: our solar system is not simply fading into empty space but is encased in a dynamic, incredibly energetic boundary. This journey of discovery, fueled by decades-old technology, continues to push the boundaries of our knowledge, reminding us that the universe always holds surprises, and the scientific process is a continuous dance between observation, prediction, and revision.
 P.S :
During my visit to DC, I went into an exposition - ‚ÄúCollecting Memories: Treasures from the Library of Congress‚Äù held at the Library of Congress, I captured an image of the Voyager Golden Record - above. The record The Sound of Eath, is on both the Voyagers. This replica is sourced from the library‚Äôs archives.
This is fascinating. I am goint to read more about the Voyager missions

title: Relearning vim selection keybindings
text: General pattern is v, i for inner, a for around or including white space, w for word, s for sentence, and p` for paragraph.

title: Relearning vim selection keybindings
text:
Select a Word

viw : select inner word (cursor anywhere in word)
vaw : select a word (includes trailing whitespace)
* then gn : search for current word, then select it
after selecting a word with viw

use Shift-U for upper case

title: Relearning vim selection keybindings
text:
Select a Sentence

vis : select inner sentence
vas : select around sentence (includes trailing whitespace)

title: Relearning vim selection keybindings
text:
Select a Paragraph

vip: select inner paragraph
vap: select around paragraph (includes trailing whitespace)

title: Relearning vim selection keybindings
text:
Select Multiple Paragraphs

vip then } : select paragraph, then expand to next paragraph. keep repeating to select more or use ‚Äò{‚Äô for de-selecting.
TipüíÅ Visual mode (v) then move with j or k to extend selection

title: Relearning vim selection keybindings
text:
Select Contents Within Braces/Brackets/Quotes etc

vi{ : select inner curly braces (text between { and })
va{ : select around curly braces (includes the braces)
vi[ : select inner square brackets
vi( : select inner parentheses
vi" : select inner double quotes
vi' : select inner single quotes
vi< : select inner angle brackets
vi< : select inner ‚Äò=‚Äô, I used for Obsidian highlights
TipüíÅ : Replace v with c in any command to change (delete and enter insert mode) instead of just selecting.

title: Roshan Padmanabhan
text:
I am a Senior Scientist, working at Trailhead Biosystems Inc. In my current role as the Director of Informatics, I spearhead THB‚Äôs bioinformatics wing where we work on implementing cutting edge transcriptomic technologies, quality control of our products, next generation sequencing pipelines and workflows.
I am passionate about AI and ML and their applications and uses in biology and medicine.
I previously worked as a Bioinformatics Scientist at Dr.¬†Mukesh Jain‚Äôs lab, Bioinformatics Postdoc Fellow at Dr.¬†Charis Eng‚Äôs lab, Bioinformatics Engineer at Remy Burcelin‚Äôs lab.

On this site I keep a list of - Publications - CV - Resume - Blog - Some Quotes that resonate




Comprehensive germline genomic profiles of children, adolescents and young adults with solid tumors link
Sankey Plots Visualization showing drug‚Äìtarget network analysis in children, adolescents, and young adults (C-AYA) with solid tumors. link
MAGI: A pipeline for whole genome comparison. link
ARG-ANNOT (Antibiotic Resistance Gene-ANNOTation)link
